PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The Toraja group, part of the Austronesian linguistic family, lives in the mountains in the island of Sulawesi.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The difficulty in defining the Toraja group arises for historical, linguistic and cultural reasons. In general, the population of the upper basin of the Sa'dan has been comprehensively studied. From the end of the nineteenth century N. Adriani and A. Kruijt began using the name ‘Toraja’ instead of ‘Alfuru’ –a name given to every highlander who was still ‘pagan’– in order to remove the negative connotation accorded the latter. At the end of the nineteenth century, the name ‘Toraja’was widely used to designate the highlanders of Central Sulawesi and the inhabitants of northern South Sulawesi. Nowadays, as a result of linguistic research, the word ‘Toraja’ is more accurately defined.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Adriani’s map in 1913, in Kruijt (Alb.) and Adriani (N.), 1912-1914, De Bare'e Sprekende Toradja's van Midden Celebes, Batavia. At the beginning of the century the Makale-Rantepao region was already clearly demarcated.

The three Toraja groups according to A. Kruijt in 1912. Three groups were called Toraja: the West-Toradja group, the Oost-Toradja group and Zuid-Toradja group, i.e., west, east and south. Today, only the communities in the south are called Toraja, designated by Kruijt using the term Zuid-Toradja. Sources: Kruijt (Alb.) and Adriani (N.), De Bare'e Sprekende Toradja's van Midden Celebes, Batavia.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: According to the linguistic map the Toraja group spreads over four departments –Tana Toraja, Polewali-Mamasa, Mamuju, and Luwu'. Recent research distinguishes several sub-families each comprising several languages. Toraja, a western Malayo-Polynesian language, is a linguistic sub-family of the northern South Sulawesi family of languages alongside Bugis, Makassar and Seko (Blust 1984-85; Friberg 1989: 16). This language consists of major dialects –also called languages –and sub-dialects. Linguists agree on the existence of five Toraja languages.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Hereditary social status governs socio-religious practices.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Social status determines the existence of different values and rituals depending on class. Rank determines a dwelling type, the type of matrimonial alliance and the type of ritual duty.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Ne’Lumbaa in front of the megalith of one of his ancestors, 2000.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Toraja society is divided into three or four status levels.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Strongly hierarchical and made up of great families, Toraja society is organized according to ranks of hereditary status diversely titled depending on the region. In the songs two classes are distinguished: the nobles ‘true men, rich, elders’ (tau tongan, tau sugi', to makaka) and ‘the numerous or thick men’(tau buda, tau kamban). The classes use an endogamy of rank and an exogamy of village. The nobles are distinguished by their capacity to celebrate a complete ritual cycle.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: A woman at the side of a noble’s catafalque, indicated by the red color and sun circle motif, 1991.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Called ‘the elders’ (to makaka), ‘the rich’ (to sugi'), the ‘big’ (to kapua), ‘the true being’ (tau tongan) –the class of nobles (tana bulaan ‘golden land’) makes up about 25% of the population. The officiants are members of this class.
‘Those in the middle’ (to tangnga) designate the iron class (tana' bassi), resulting from the marriage between nobles and commoners. Rich, they are also called ‘the elders’ (to makaka).

The commoners are called in Toraja ‘the multitude’ (to kamban), ‘the numerous people’ (to buda) or ‘the bundle of bamboos’ (to bulo dia’pa’) or ‘the poor’ (to bongko). In the south, this class is called ‘the palm wood class’ (tana' karurung).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From a song evoking the difference between nobles and commoners, recorded at Tiroan (Bittuang), 1993.
From a simbong evoking the difference between nobles and commoners, collected 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the south of Rantepao, there was a class of dependants known as to kaunan (‘servants, dependants’) or ‘class of the grass trampled under foot’(tana' kua-kua). In the north, this class is not present and so is not mentioned in the songs. Despite the abolition of slavery by the Dutch at the beginning of the century there are still dependants in families not converted to Christianity.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: It is possible, through marriage and the rituals, to change status.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The Toraja do form a stratified society, but not strictly so in so far as, on the one hand, a woman can become noble by marrying a man more noble than herself, and on the other, the funeral celebration –a trampoline for social competition –enables members of the lower classes to acquire a new status if they succeed in completing a ritual cycle at the highest level.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Palanquin of the deceased carried at a funeral ritual, Tapparan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Society is organized into great families (rapuan), among whom a strong extended family feeling prevails.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The stem family corresponds to the Toraja term rapuan designating a group of cognate descent from a common ancestor, the founder of the ancestral house tongkonan; in fact it refers to a vast structure with a highly significant role at the great rituals (Nooy-Palm 1979:26).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Celebrated house, at a ma’kurre sumanga’ (Catholic thanksgiving ritual), Bittuang, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: In the songs, the noble class is praised for its grandeur.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the songs, the value of the nobility is told through different metaphors such as gold, metal, trees, birds of prey, jewels, and paddy fields.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Nobles with their backs to a megalith during Ne’Sulo’s funeral, 2000.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The great trees –banyan (lamba', barana’), sandalwood (sendana), and Michelia celebica (uru) –designate rich and powerful beings, able to protect and counsel.

Gold (bulayan) is omnipresent in the words of the songs. The noble being is created using gold. Children are conceived from gold. The nobles are praised through gold: all the badong songs have as final expressions word such as: ‘gold necklace’ (rara' bulayan), ‘gold leaf’ (dom bulayan); ‘golden hairbun’ (lokkon bulayan) refers to an illustrious woman, ‘golden horns’ (tanduk bulayan) to a glorious man.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Red and gold coffin, reserved for the nobles, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Kris (gayang, sarapang) and sabers (penainna), are the metaphors for masculine nobility. Cutting-edged weapons are associated with magic power. Gayang designates a golden kris, metaphor for a young noble boy. Sarapang designates a great golden kris, metaphor for a man of importance. Praise often found is ‘thick kris’ (gayang pirri').

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Kris at a maro ritual, Torea village, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Ancestral textiles appear in several categories: maa', sarita, and langgesa’. The maa’ textiles were introduced by the East India Company (VOC), which imported these cottons from India. They are held to possess magic powers that can affect prosperity. The sarita and other sacred fabrics were, according to the Toraja, made of divine thread (Veen 1965: 92-93). Accordingly, they were used in diverse ways during the rituals: attached to long bamboo masts in front of the deceased’s house, bound round the funeral effigy’s head, and hung as ceremonial banners from the houses (Nooy-Palm 1979: 257; Gittinger 1989: 202).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Tombi, ceremonial cloth attached to a stake and planted on the sacrificial site, Bokko 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The nobility is also associated with birds: cocks, falcons, egrets, silvery-cheeked hornbills, swifts. Only the noble have the right to show a sculpted bird on their façades.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The class of nobles is identified by its exemplarity.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The noble is exemplary on every level: he makes a good marriage, possesses a magnificent family (rapu); he is enterprising both as farmer and businessman –he can admirably exchange rice for buffaloes, he is a master of weaving and metal-working; he is distinguished by his piety, his aptitude to perform the highest rituals, and his punctilious honor. These are reflected in the quantity and quality of meat he receives during the rituals.

ETAPE.TITRE: The village, between West and East.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The villages are built following the axes West/East and Upstream/Downstream.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Like many peoples in Indonesia, the Toraja orient themselves using the path of the sun and the course of the rivers. The West and downstream are associated with the world of the ancestors, death and the color black. The East and upstream are associated with the world of the divinities, prosperity and orange-yellow.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Orientation of Toraja houses and granaries.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Around the village, the West and downstream are associated with the world of the deceased and the ancestors.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Downstream is the direction of the non-deified ancestors’world. The setting sun also refers to the directions west and downstream. It represents the side of death, funerals, and the transformation of shades into ancestors. After the rituals held on their behalf, the shades leave down the river Sa'dan, towards Enrekang, to travel to a place called Puyo. The ancestors are held to have arrived originally following a route from southwest to northeast, when they crossed the sea from the mythical island of Pongko' aboard eight ships (Nooy Palm 1979: 112-114).

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Downstream is the direction of the world of non-deified ancestors. Various terms designate downstream: sau' ‘going downstream’, lo' ‘down there’, diong ‘below’.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The East and upstream are associated with the world of the divinities and deified ancestors.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The East is called matallo (‘sun’ allo). It is the residence of the divinities and deified ancestors.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Linked to heaven and to the rituals of prosperity and fecundity, upstream stands for the world above, the home of the divinities (deata), gods (puang), and deified ancestors (nene' mendeata). These divinities are not well defined: certain are named, most are not. The rituals of the East enable them to be contacted by means of the songs and offerings made at the northeast of the rice granary. Various terms designate upstream: rekke ‘going upstream’, da ‘above’, do ‘upwards’.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The sites of the rituals of the East.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The sites of the East rituals are known as ‘places of liberty’ (kala'paran) or ‘markets’ (pasa' maro, ‘pasa' bugi'), for the exchanges between humans and divinities take place there.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The ancestral houses are erected following cosmological polarities.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The front of the house, facing the rice granary, looks upstream in the direction of the divinities, while the back looks downstream towards the ancestors. In the house the kitchen is in the East; the parents sleep in the room on the south and the children to the north; only the dead rest with the head downstream and the body lying along the West wall, towards the home of the dead, in the southwest of Tana Toraja, down the river Sa'dan.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The village space is organized around great noble houses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A hamlet comprises one or several houses in a line facing one or several rice granaries, which are architectural replicas of the houses. The courtyard area is between the houses and the granaries. In the words of the songs a house’s nobility is underlined by its position in space and time (it is the place where the ancestral fabrics are kept), by its architecture, by the quality of its various parts, the richness of its kitchen and its wooden engravings.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Called banua or tongkonan (from tongkon ‘sit down’), the houses are dwelling places, reserved for the nobility.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: In front of the house, Lempopoton, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: As everywhere in Southeast Asia, the house is not just a dwelling place but the symbol of a huge family, a ‘house of the ancestors’, the place of origin of a stem family or sub-stem-family –a house is an institution representing a dominant family (MacDonald 1987: 196, Volkman 1985: 44-58). Every Toraja traces his descent in relation to a varying number of houses of origin: to his parents’, grandparents’, and ancestors’birth places. This indicates the rank of nobility.

The rank of nobility of the house is determined through different features: its origin in the village (mother house or not), its constituent elements, its size, its construction type, its external sculptures, its internal riches, and also by the abundance of the rice granaries facing it. The song of the East (simbong) includes in one of its parts a panegyric to the house (sampa' banua).
The house is the social and ritual center around which all the rituals and, consequently, a large part of musical life are organized.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: In front of the house at Deri, at a bua’ kasalle, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The traditional houses of the Austronesian world possess a vitality of their own, depending on the vitality of their occupants and the objects they contain (Waterson 1991: 115). Considered a real living structure endowed with a vital energy, the house is sung and celebrated, and –just like a human being –undergoes rites of passage.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The motifs engraved (sura') on the wooden exterior façades of the houses and rice granaries are painted in four colors –red, yellow, white and black. Their abundance, variety, and nature determine the house’s status. Only the nobles have the right to motifs on the house's four façades; moreover, certain motifs on wood are exclusively theirs. The motifs are rich and symmetrical. Their distribution obeys a precise order. Every motif draws its name from a reference to daily life (objects, utensils), or nature (plants, animals, domestic utensils).

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the west of the Toraja Sa'dan country, in the Mamasa district, the houses are not only decorated with wood engravings but also with carvings in the round of male human figurines on horse-back.

Depending on rank the façades are decorated with the heads of different animals: buffaloes, cocks, birds, serpents. These animals play an important role in the myths. The cock and the buffalo are held to be agents of transformation, who ensure the transfer of the deceased’s wealth and restore life (Waterson 1989: 66).

The number of granaries is a sign of the stem family’wealth.

ETAPE.TITRE: The rituals from the West to the East.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The rituals of the West relate to funerals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: On the side of the West, the funeral rituals represent simply the beginning of a much vaster ritual process centered on the transformation of a life spirit into a black shade and then an ancestor.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The rituals of the East relate the fecundity of the land, animals and humans.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: After the funerals, the rituals of the East begin. They transform the deceased’s shade into vital energy or divinity by making it ascend Eastwards through a series of graded rites of passage.

ETAPE.TITRE: Turning around from one side to the other.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Turning around, i.e., the necessary passage from the West to the East, is the principle on which the ritual dynamic is based.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The turnaround obliges every being to ‘turn around’a funeral rite with a rite in the East. It enables the shade to change into an ancestor and then into divinity so as to regain its vital energy. Prosperity is only possible if this turnaround is performed: filial duty is only fulfilled after this assistance to the dead transforms the deceased into ancestors, through the performance of the rituals of the East. The ritual cycle itself is called ‘rule of turnaround’(aluk pembalikan).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Ritual journey for a deceased of noble class.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Turning around in the words of the songs.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the ossoran badong and samparan simbong narratives, the turnaround is described literally.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The principle of turning around invades the whole of the religious system.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The recurrent turnaround principle is expressed either symbolically through the names attributed to certain rites or the values expressed in the ritual words, or physically by inverting something (the corpse, the effigy, the offerings, the mast bate, the vowels, for example).

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The ‘rule of turnaround’(aluk pembalikan) upholds the whole socio-religious system of which the dynamic consists in ‘turning around’from the West to the East. It represents ‘turning around’(i.e. to pass) a ritual from the side of the West to the side of the East, from one point opposite to another. The ultimate aim of the aluk pembalikan is the return of the deceased’s gift to the living: the living give cooked food to the dead, and in return the dead offer the living protection and fecundity. The society’s relationships are globally determined by this system of exchange. Note: Hetty Nooy-Palm translates pembalikan using the English term ‘conversion’as‘means of restoring relations with the gods of the world above’(Nooy-Palm 1986: 152-153).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The expression in the songs of the duty to turn around.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the West, the first act of the great funerals consists of changing the corpse’s position from east-west to north-south. The rite is called ‘turning the deceased around ‘(ma'pabaliki to mate). ‘The deceased is turned around’, with the head to the south, and is then deemed ready to leave for the place of the ancestors, known as Puya.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The widow lying in an inverse position to the deceased, To'Barana', 2000.
VIDEO: From the changing of the deceased‘s position, To' Barana', June 2000.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Some days later, during the funeral, the effigy, the substitute for the deceased, is put outside the house and turned from the west to the east (pembalikan tau-tau), after which animal and musical offerings are made to it. This change of direction reveals the future destination of the deceased’s soul.

The ‘turning the drum around ‘(pembalikan gandang), can take place some considerable time after the great funeral. This constitutes the final funeral rite that consecrates the transformation of the deceased’s soul into divinity by a simple drum stroke together with the sacrifice of a pig on the sacrificial field. The drum itself is not ‘turned around’; rather the deceased’s soul changes direction, passing from the south to the north, so as to be transformed into divinity (mendeata) (Waterson 1993: 74).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Drum used as place for offerings during the maro; here, Ne' Mendolo, Torea, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the rituals of the East, at the start of every ritual, the action consists of symbolically turning the offering around (pembalikan pesungna) (Veen 1966: 6; Nooy-Palm 1986: 152). The offering consists of placing cooked meat and rice on a banana leaf. The meat is placed upstream, the home of gods and divinities, then after a speech, the banana leaf is turned around in the opposite direction so that the meat is directed downstream, the home of the ancestors. This fundamental act, necessary for the souls’passage from one world to the other, structures the system of thought. No funeral rite is considered complete until this ritual has been performed.

A ritual of the East, maro bate ma'pabalik ( ‘turning the mast around’) is performed so that the soul of the deceased may pass from the West to the East, and from low to high, towards the place of the divinities. During this ritual, one or more great trident masts are erected. They are said to be ‘turned around’, as they are equivalent to the mast erected during the celebrations of the West.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Celebration of the East: bate at the maro, Sereale, 1993.
Celebration of the West: bandera at a funeral, To' Barana', June 2000.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: This turnaround is a process of regeneration, turning the deceased into ‘life spirit’.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Funeral rituals are only the beginning of a much vaster ritual process centered on the deceased’s reproduction and regeneration as ‘life spirit’ deata and ‘vital energy’ sumanga’. The shade of the dead noble is transformed into an ancestor and then into a divinity through a series of rites of passage, which are graduated and orientated in space from the West to the East.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The dynamic balance between left and right must be maintained.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: This entails placing a ritual of the East on the same level as a ritual of the West of the same rank: each rite must have its ‘answer’ (bali) for the cycle to be completed and the deceased’s shade transformed into divinity, full of vital energy (sumanga').

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Graduation entails a succession of ever greater rituals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In ‘the rule of the ladder with rungs matching each other like two halves of bamboo’(aluk silau' eran simuane tallang), the rungs are organized like the ‘bamboos of a Toraja roof’, with ever larger elements –more and more important rituals. In this way the rituals form a hierarchy. This graduation can be seen from a succession of names for the rites –in ever increasing order of importance referring to greater and greater rituals.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Graduation in the words of the songs.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: These seven names correspond to the seven rungs of the East that every noble is obliged to travel after the performance of the two-stage funerals that balance the left part with the right. He must climb all the rungs in the East, right up to the bua’ kasalle.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From the song mentioning the graduation. Ossoran badong, lines 493 to 502. 1993, Randanan, Pangngala'.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the words of the songs, the ritual graduation is compared to the construction of a roof. Toraja roofs are built according to a specific technique in which larger and larger bamboos are fitted into one another.

ETAPE.TITRE: The guardians of the ritual order.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The overall officiant (to minaa).
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: ‘He who knows’(to minaa) is the senior officiant, the great specialist in ritual language and usages. He officiates both at the funeral and the fecundity celebrations. As a member of the middle class, he leads a life similar to other farmers. As an intercessor and mediator between visible and invisible worlds, he pronounces the words that enable the deceased, family or house to ‘change status’.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: To minaa Gandang Barani, also called ‘He who beats the drum’ To Ma' Gandang or To minaa Manakka. Though his name is associated with the drum and with the resonant voice he does not play the drum and is not a particularly good singer. He can enumerate the seven layers of the cosmos.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: To minaa Ulu Manuk (The Chicken-headed Savant’) is an officiant whose pay is no more than a chicken head because he is not able to officiate during the great celebrations. He is also called To minaa Sa'de Banua (‘The Savant beside the House’), because his knowledge afford him to officiate only close to the house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The officiant(ess) of the rituals of the East: to burake.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Two types of burake exist. In the south, the burake tambolang (‘white heron’) which is a transvestite, in the north, the burake tattiku' (‘little bird of the mountains’), man or woman. The first acquires his title by nature, the second inherits it. Today, the first type has disappeared. Burake may mean ‘impotent’or ‘hermaphrodite’(Nooy-Palm 1979: 282). He/she officiated in the agrarian rituals (menani pare) and/or in the bua’ kasalle. His status diminished throughout the century due to the disappearance of the rituals of the East.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Ne' Lumbaa and Pong Limbong, two burake tattiku’, preparing offerings for the bua’ kasalle, Bamba (Deri), 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Object of the officiant(ess) burake: a drum.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Priest or priestess of the rituals of the East, performing at the bua’ kasalle, gifted for singing, the to burake has a small hand drum called garatung, a pellet drum with two python skins, with ball strikers. He/she uses it for all the rituals he/she directs to give a rhythm to her words through the drum’s biting sound.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Burake Lumbaa shaking his pellet drum during a prayer, bua’ kasalle, Bamba (Deri), 1993.
Burake Lumbaa turning around the platform with his pellet drum, Bamba (Deri), 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: I have worked with several to burake of both sexes from the Tallu Kalo'na region. They are active within their society, and regularly receive neighbors who come for advice on life and rituals.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Recurrence of the transvestite officiants in South Sulawesi.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Sacred homosexuality is still found in South Sulawesi, with the clergy of the transvestite priests (bissu), homosexual officiants, shamans, priests, specialists in trance ritual, and intermediaries between men and Gods (Hamonic 1987). This existed in Java in the past and it was frequent among the shamans of the Bare'e in Central Sulawesi, Bali, among certain Dayak of Borneo, in some communities in Formosa, the Philippines and Polynesia (Kroef 1956). Incidence of the term burake in Central Sulawesi (tadumburake among the Mori, wura'e or balia near Palu, in Kruijt 1912 and Stockhof 1984).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: At Pare-Pare, a bissu priest and an ex-priest, 1991.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: ‘He who sings’(to menani), master of praise.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: ‘He who sings’(to menani) is an officiant at the bua’ ritual. His title is hereditary (disoso'i). He has false buffalo horns, in brass, called tanduk batara lolo ‘young divinity’s horn’and is dressed in yellow. He is an expert in praise and eulogy. He is responsible for different invocations in the bua’ celebrations –bua’ padang and bua’ sangrapu; his role is less important than the officiant burake’s: he declaims the singgi' and sura' tedong incantations. His funeral is inverted into a celebration of fecundity.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Ne' Tato’Dena’, to menani and to minaa with his son, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The officiant of the rituals of the West: the to mebalun.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The mortician is called to mebalun ‘he who wraps’to burake bombo (‘officiant of the shade’) or to burake matampu’ (‘officiant of the setting sun’) (Nooy Palm 1979: 280). Descended from a slave, he is on the margins of society, lives in isolation and has the right to attend only funeral rituals. This function was effected by a slave in the south of the Toraja country. He is the most important officiant at the first funeral celebration after which, at the second celebration, he yields his place to the to minaa.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The death wrapper, to mebalun, with the widow at Ne’Sulo’s funeral, 2000.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: At the funerals I attended (October 1993 and May 2000), the mortician, about fifty years old, was called on for the second day of the celebration. This man, gloomy and always busy, is not very approachable. His role is to attend to the deceased and the widow or widower. His tasks are many: he rolls up the corpse and feeds it, constructs all types of objects, has the widow(er) undergo the rites of passage, and must sacrifice a large number of piglets which he cooks as a gift to the deceased.
